thread.title: If you live in a Hurricane Milton-affected county, you get an IRS tax deadline extension
thread.title_full: If you live in a Hurricane Milton-affected county, you get an IRS tax deadline extension

author: C. A. Bridges
title: If you live in a Hurricane Milton-affected county, you get an IRS tax deadline extension
text: If you live in a Hurricane Milton-affected county, you get an IRS tax deadline extension [C. A. Bridges](/staff/5204967002/c-a-bridges/) People dealing with the [aftermath of Hurricane Milton](/story/news/nation/2024/10/11/hurricane-milton-live-updates-friday/75624425007/) have one less thing to worry about, for now. The Internal Revenue Service announced today that tax deadlines for people in the 51 counties under a [state of emergency](/story/news/hurricane/2024/10/07/desantis-state-of-emergency-florida-hurricane-milton/75550378007/) during the storm would be pushed back to May 1, 2025. Combined with previous tax relief provided for taxpayers in counties affected by Hurricane Debby and Hurricane Helene, that means affected taxpayers "in all of Florida" now have until May next year to file various federal individual and business tax returns and make tax payments, the IRS said kn a release, including 2024 individual and business returns normally due during March and April 2025, and 2023 individual and corporate returns with valid extensions and quarterly estimated tax payments. What is the new IRS deadline for people affected by Hurricane Milton? Affected taxpayers now have until May 1, 2025, to file various federal individual and business tax returns and make tax payments, including 2024 individual and business returns normally due during March and April 2025 and 2023 individual and corporate returns with valid extensions and quarterly estimated tax payments. Who is eligible for Hurricane Milton tax relief? - Individuals who live in the covered disaster area - Businesses (including tax-exempt organizations) whose principal place of business is located in the covered disaster area - Taxpayers who are not in the covered disaster area, but whose records necessary to meet a deadline are in the covered disaster area - All relief workers affiliated with a recognized government or philanthropic organization assisting in the relief activities in the covered disaster area - Any individual visiting the covered disaster area who was killed or injured as a result of the disaster Which counties are included in the Hurricane Milton tax relief? The affected areas include Alachua, Baker, Bradford, Brevard, Broward, Charlotte, Citrus, Clay, Collier, Columbia, DeSoto, Dixie, Duval, Flagler, Gilchrist, Glades, Hamilton, Hardee, Hendry, Hernando, Highlands, Hillsborough, Indian River, Lafayette, Lake, Lee, Levy, Madison, Manatee, Marion, Martin, Miami-Dade, Monroe, Nassau, Okeechobee, Orange, Osceola, Palm Beach, Pasco, Pinellas, Polk, Putman, Sarasota, Seminole, St. Johns, St. Lucie, Sumter, Suwannee, Taylor, Union and Volusia counties. Hurricane Milton mauls Florida:[City and county guide to death, misery and destruction](/story/news/hurricane/2024/10/10/hurricane-milton-a-florida-damage-breakdown-by-city-photos-sarasota-tampa-fort-myers-naples-daytona/75604302007/) What does the new IRS deadline apply to? The May 1, 2025, filing deadline applies to: - Any individual or business that has a 2024 return normally due during March or April 2025. - Any individual, C corporation or tax-exempt organization that has a valid extension to file their calendar-year 2023 federal return. The IRS noted, however, that payments on these returns are not eligible for the extra time because they were due last spring before the hurricane occurred. - 2024 quarterly estimated tax payments normally due on Jan. 15, 2025, and 2025 estimated tax payments normally due on April 15, 2025. - Quarterly payroll and excise tax returns normally due on Oct. 31, 2024, Jan. 31, 2025, and April 30, 2025. Also, any penalties on payroll and excise tax deposits due on or after Oct. 5, 2024, and before Oct. 21, 2024, will be abated as long as the tax deposits are made by Oct. 21, 2024. You can find more information at the IRS' [disaster assistance and emergency relief for individuals and businesses](https://www.irs.gov/businesses/small-businesses-self-employed/disaster-assistance-and-emergency-relief-for-individuals-and-businesses) page as well as information on other returns, payments and tax-related actions qualifying for relief during the postponement period.
